10.04 a.m.
SINGAPORE CONSTITUTION EXPOSITION
(Participation by Government)
(Statement by the Chief Minister)


    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission I wish to make a statement on the participation of the Government in the Singapore Constitution Exposition which is being organised by the Chinese Chamber of Commerce in celebration of the achievement of a new Constitution next year giving birth to a self-governing State of Singapore. The emphasis of this Exposition is national, instilling loyalty and pride in Singapore and in its constitutional development, for at this time of the celebration it must be the wish of everyone of us that every citizen in our predominantly young population should share the significance and exhilaration of that event.

    This new Constitution is coming to us because of our own unity, determination and steady constitutional efforts, and it gives us the reality and the substance of freedom in our internal affairs. To change the title and status of Colony for that of a State is a major and irrevocable step in our history and a matter of great pride and joy for our people.

Column: 901



    The emphasis of all exhibits in the Exposition will be on the achievement of self-government, but it was clear that, without major Government participation, the emphasis would not be readily understood. It is essential that there should be a Government Pavilion to emphasise the fact, nature, extent and reality of the constitutional change and to show the advances already made under the impetus of an elected government which we expect will be the greater when the fully elected Government under the new Constitution takes over.

    Moreover, it is important to emphasise the wide range of services which the Government provides for the welfare, prosperity and security of the people of Singapore. The Government Pavilion will come as the climax of our activities in civic education whose aim has been to ensure that the fullest and widest use is made of the opportunity to vote, which has been conferred by our citizenship legislation last year.

    100,000 square feet have been reserved free of charge for the Government within the demarcated area of the Exposition. The Committee under the chairmanship of the Assistant Minister to the Chief Secretary (Mr M. P. D. Nair) has been preparing plans and estimates in consultation with the Ministries. It is proposed to build a covered space of 60,000 square feet. It will be in two parts, each facing on to the main axis of the Exposition; one showing the Government's part in increasing the wealth and economic prosperity of the country, and the other showing the wide range of social services in health, education and welfare which the Government provides for the people. Details of cost have not yet been worked out to an extent which allows the Govermnent to ask for a specific sum to be voted, but every means is being sought to achieve economy by using materials which will be required for other purposes next year and by borrowing of material and equipment. Moreover, exhibits are being designed in such a way that they can be of long-term use for departmental activities afterwards.

    For the need to win the unity, understanding and co-operation of our

Column: 902

citizens is a task as continuous as the democratic process itself, and I am sure this Assembly will wish that this exhibit should be of a standard to match not only the general standard of the Exposition but also of the theme of the new Constitution.

    Sir, I have another statement to make clear the policy of the Government in relation to the recent ban on the importation of publications from certain publishers -

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar) rose -

    Mr Speaker: Point of order?

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: On a point of order, Sir. Surely the Chief Minister does not wish us to be inundated by a series of statements before we have recovered from his first one?

    Mr Speaker: Actually I take it that the Chief Minister would welcome questions on his first statement, and therefore, perhaps he will pause now and if hon. Members wish to ask questions on his first statement, they may do so.

    The Chief Minister: When they mooted this idea, the Chinese Chamber of Commerce thought of a trade fair on art international basis, and when they saw me they felt that a better emphasis would be on the achievement of self-government. Hence the name of that trade fair has been changed to that of Constitution Exposition.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Am I right in believing that, as a result of the persuasive powers of the Chief Minister, he has successfully engaged the Chinese Chamber of Commerce in politics?

    The Chief Minister: I have not endeavoured to persuade the Chinese Chamber of Commerce. Perhaps it is surprising to the Member for Tanjong Pagar that there are citizens in Singapore today who have a keen desire to show their loyalty to Singapore.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: No one doubts the desire of everybody to evince their loyalty. I am asking the Chief Minister whether this political slant that has been given to the trade exposition is a result of the intervention of the Chief Minister?

BAN ON IMPORTATION OF
PUBLICATIONS FROM CHINA
AND HONGKONG
(Government policy)


    The Chief Minister: May I now proceed with another statement, Sir, in relation to the recent ban on the importation of publications from certain publishers in China and Hongkong? Sir, I would like to emphasise that this was not a change of policy but a tightening up of the application of our policy. Previously, all books had been allowed to enter except those specifically banned. This was appropriate when there was still a certain amount of freedom for publishers, and classics and textbooks in particular were re-published untouched from the freer days of Chinese culture.

    But with the change of policy in China and the subordination of all publishing houses, and through the process of rectification of all writers to the Communist Party, this laxity could not be allowed to remain unchecked, for with an import of a million publications a month from China and Hongkong, there can be no guarantee that the assessment and sifting can be complete. It is therefore the procedure now that only books which are specifically exempted for the cultural and

Column: 904

academic value of their contents, and which have not been reduced by editing, presentation or selection to the level of Hsueh Hsi textbooks, will be allowed to enter.

    We appreciate, Sir, that this has caused temporary hardship to those in the book trade, but every step is being taken to speed up our processes of assessment of existing books, so that exemptions among those already here and for the future can also be given speedily. It has been encouraging that the grounds of our policy have been generally accepted and that there is appreciation of the need at this time of democratic nation-building to prevent the weight of other external ideologies and nationalisms drowning our own.

    This is the logic of citizenship in action, and it is for us, by our mental reactions and by our actions, to show that citizenship based on exclusive and active loyalty to Malaya is a reality, and an axiom of our political thought and action. If it can be shown to us that this action pf ours weakens the forces of democracy or inhibits the growth of our new patriotism, then we are in the wrong. But no responsible government in Singapore can accept criticism based on any outlook which is not Malayan.

    I realise that we cannot merely create a vacuum and that the ultimate answer is the production of writing of our own with a Malayan atmosphere and a Malayan outlook. I would appeal, therefore, to all writers to direct their thoughts and words to the lives and aspirations and problems of the peoples of Malaya; and to publishers in all languages to give our writers encouragement by offering publication and distribution facilities.

    We cannot produce best-sellers straightaway, but now is the time for those who have had the benefit of our rapidly growing education and who feel the new forces of democratic constitutional nation-building to express that positive creative force for those who are less explicit and begin to make our own contribution to the world of arts.

    Sir, before I make the final statement, I would welcome questions from the other side of the House.

imported - including a lot of classics by Confucius and Lao-tze, and books on the arts, too, such as music, medicine and science - have any political significance; and also whether the Chief Minister is aware that in certain universities and libraries there are thousands of books classified as research work, such as the classics, books on science or special studies, and has he any concrete evidence that those books have any political significance?

Say, for example compare the works of Shakespeare with the Chinese classic The Red Chamber Dream.

    The Chief Minister: Sir, I think the hon. Member has not understood my statement well. I said, regarding the classics, books of art and science, so long as they have not been contaminated by any attempt to subordinate them to the Communist doctrine, they are not going to be banned. In fact, they are indeed welcomed. What I am appealing to is that, since we are all conscious of a new nation being born in Malaya, and since we have each and every one

Column: 907

of us declared that we love Malaya, surely there are bound to be some people in Malaya who will be able to contribute in this world of art.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Can the Chief Minister give an illustration of such a contamination for the benefit of the public?

    The Chief Minister: It may interest the hon. Member, Sir, to know that I am having a White Paper compiled.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Mr Speaker, Sir, just now the Chief Minister touched on Malayan loyalty. He has a suspicion that the books from China are going to cause the Chinese in Singapore to withdraw their loyalty to Malaya. Does the Chief Minister know that a lot of books from Taipeh and Hongkong have been financed by the U.S.I.S., and that they go out to the local overseas Chinese calling on them to support the Chiang Kai-shek regime? Does the Chief Minister consider this also harmful to this country? If he wants to ban the 53 publishers, can he tell us how many publishers there are in Taipeh and Hong-Kong who are supporting the Chiang Kai-shek regime and trying to woo the support of the overseas Chinese and who should be banned?

    The Chief Minister: Sir, in our desire and attempt to build up a Malayan nationhood, any attempt by outside forces to thwart that objective is wrong.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Chief Minister, your third statement.

Column: 907

DUMPING OF CHINESE TEXTILES INTO FEDERATION OF MALAYA


    The Chief Minister: I have one final statement to make, Sir, and it is in regard to the decision of the Government to assist the Federation of Malaya by limiting the dumping of Chinese cottons into the Malayan economic unit of which we are a part and a beneficiary. Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not concerned now with the details of the decision, but wish to emphasise again that criticisms must be related to the new stage of our constitutional develop-

Column: 908

ment. It is the clear assumption of our new constitution that it is the last stage before independence through merger with the Federation. We accept, with understanding but without loss of faith in our ultimate objective, the position that it is not the present policy of the Federation that there should be merger now.

    Meanwhile, Sir, Singapore cannot afford a running bickering battle with the Federation hoping to win every time; for not only will that snot be to our long-term economic interest, but it is no way to show our readiness to share our fortunes with them for better and for worse, in riches and in poverty. This does not make us a colony or a slave of the Federation, or any other noun which is culled from the dictionary of denunciation. We must be realistic and even the partnership of equals and independents assumes a great deal of give and take.

    My appeal is, therefore, that in all our discussions of issues of this kind we must start from a Malayan assumption and we must show towards the Federation the consideration we expect from them. This may not be an easy policy to follow, but again we must realistically face facts and not ignore them. And one of these facts is that if we claim to be a part of a Malayan nation seeking the rightful union which circumstances deny us today, we must act as a part of a Malayan nation here and now.

    Let us remember the essential elements of policy such as citizenship, education and multilingualism which we are able to follow without question, and ask ourselves before we let loose the full flood of criticism whether the issue is important enough to put the constitution and the policies it enshrines in jeopardy. Only by trial and error, approaching each issue reasonably, can we begin to reach agreement.

    There must be the will and the mood; and then our future will be the stronger together, because of the mutual confidence, the mutual co-operation which has been worked out voluntarily. As each stone is laid by agreement and

Column: 909

cemented by mutual respect and appreciation, the joint home of Malayan independence will be the stronger and more rapidly built.

Column: 909

FLOOD PREVENTION
(Statement by the Minister for Communications and Works)


10.29 a.m.

    Mr Francis Thomas: Mr Speaker, Sir, some hon. Members will probably have received, communications from their constituents as a result of the flooding caused by heavy rain on Monday last, the 3rd of November, and I think it may be useful if I make a statement on what has been achieved so far by the Government's flood control works; on what remains to be done; and on the broad picture, in short, as it is today and as far as we can forsee it for the next few years.

    I had better start by enumerating some of the basic simple points to which I have referred in the past in the Assembly, but which may not be clear in hon. Members' recollection.

    The first point is that we have to get the water right off the land and into the sea, or else we have to retain it in a properly planned and constructed reservoir. It would be useless to approach this flooding problem on a short-term vote-catching basis. It would be fairly easy sometimes to shift the flood water off the land of political supporters and on to the land of political opponents. But I would not wish to do that and I am sure that my honourable political opponents on the Opposition Benches would not wish me to do it to them. The only way to deal with flood problems is by proper overall schemes after a full study of the facts.

    My second point is that flooding cannot be dealt with as simply as some people suppose. It is not just a matter of deepening or widening the channels of the drains. If deepening brings the bottom of the drain down to sea level, then the sea will flow up the drain at high tide, and this is not a desirable result. The only way of stopping this

Column: 910

is to have a fairly expensive tidal gate at the mouth of the drain, such as we have put in at the mouth of the Geylang River.

    Moreover, even where the land is above sea level, deepening of a drain may have serious results. It lowers the water table and dries out the subsoil. For example, in the Queenstown area, the land has been reclaimed by putting earth-fill on top of swamp mud. A deepening of the drain would lower the water table and dry out the foundations and thus affect the stability of the houses.

    Even where no buildings would suffer from deepening the drains, lowering the water table will draw away the water from the roots of the farmers' crops and then they cannot grow their vegetables for the market.

    The third point is that flood difficulties are very much increased as development proceeds. This operates in two ways. Firstly, every new piece of development increases both the size and the speed of the run-off of water. Along Bukit Timah Road, each new estate that is developed sends more water down more quickly to the lower parts of the roads. In the same way along Thomson Road on Sunday last I was asked by residents to look at a local flooding problem. Although it was some hours after the rain had stopped, I found a house where six inches of watery mud was still standing in and around the house and this was being accumulated by being trapped between the old and the new Thomson Roads. Residents nearby on the other side of the new Thomson Road telephoned me on Monday to say that their houses which had never been flooded before, were being flooded now. I have not yet got a final report on this particular area. I quote it because it illustrates the danger of new development sending flood waters down to people at the bottom of the hills.

    Development also causes flooding difficulties when it puts valuable capital investment on to land which would otherwise have been used for drainage. For example, the flooding below the Peirce Reservoir to which I was just

Column: 911

referring could have been dealt with by a drain out towards Ponggol but before the drain could be surveyed or constructed or even planned the appropriate line for it had been covered by development at Serangoon Garden Estate and that way out is now closed.

    The fourth point I should make is the problem of achieving co-ordination between different authorities. The City Council in the City area has to deal with water which is flowing down to them from the rural area and in the rural area the decisions which have been or will be made about the three big City Council reservoirs in the centre of the island affect the planning of flood control works from Mandai right down to Potong Pasir. To co-ordinate plans between separate authorities is never easy.

    My fifth general point is that adequate flood control schemes are very expensive. They not only take a lot of construction work but they also involve big requirements for land; and in the overcrowded state of Singapore, land requirement means also heavy costs for land clearance and resettlement. Hon. Members will have seen in the Press reports of the complaints by residents in the Aljunied Road area who were reluctant to move off the land required for the drains for our second tidal gate in the area.

    So much for these general points which hon. Members would like to bear in mind as I go forward with a brief account of the flooding which occurred last Monday and how it is related to the plans which Government has carried out or now has in hand.

    I have no reports of flooding from the eastern side of the island. The flood control scheme at Bedok seems to have been 100 per cent successful. A little further west, in the Geylang Serai area, our new tidal gate which is associated with some drainage works carried out by the City Council seems also to have been fully successful. Higher up in the Lorong Tai Seng area, there was some water lying about when I visited it and I am afraid that situation will remain and will have to be accepted until we have completed

Column: 912

our second tidal gate in the Kallang swamp on the other side of Aljunied Road and cleared the land and dug the drains which will carry the water away from the Airport Road area.

    I have no reports of significant flooding from Potong Pasir but, as I mentioned just now, there was some local flooding all the way up Thomson Road from Kampong San Teng as far as the Sembawang Hills Estate.

    So much for the eastern side of the island. As far as reports to me go, there was no other significant flooding there. The rainfall on the eastern side of the island was not so heavy as the rainfall on the western side of the island.

    As I pointed out earlier, development along the Bukit Timah Road produces an increasingly rapid run-off and concentration of water along Bukit Timah Road and through to Orchard Road. Although the rainfall this year was very much less than it was in the serious flood period of 1954, the flood levels at the bottom of Bukit Timah Road were considerably higher than they were in 1954. For example, in front of the University of Malaya, there were 2½ feet of water and there were three feet of water at the Orchard Road/Scotts Road junction, the water coming there from the same source.

    The flooding of this area is one of the major problems which will have to be dealt with in the future. The only practical solution is to get the water away from here by a very big ring drain run- fling along Whitley Road across Thomson Road through the south of Toa Payoh down to the Kallang swamp. This will involve very large works and, consequently, a lot of money.

    Further south, we have the very serious and rapidly increasing flooding along the catchment of the Singapore River. At Upper Queenstown, there was a big accumulation of water and further down in the low-lying area, the floods were as much as three feet in depth.

    Here again, flooding has been created where it had not previously existed by the very large development works being carried out at the head of the catchment.

Column: 913

This is the third major flood control scheme which the Government is carrying out. Putting it briefly, we are cutting through the line of the Railway and propose to run the water away to the west into the sea.

    There is also an increasing flood area in the City around Robinson Road, Boon Tat Street and Cecil Street. My colleague, the Minister for Local Government, informed this Assembly in July 1955 that the City Council had schemes for pounding areas beneath the area of Boat Quay and Telok Ayer at a cost of about $450,000. I have no recent information about City Council proposals for work in this area but the inconvenience caused to this vital commercial area by flooding must be considerable.

    I have not had reports of any serious flooding further west in the Jurong and Ama Keng areas, though, no doubt, in any heavy rain there will be some accumulation of water.

    I must not conceal from hon. Members that, had the tide been higher or had the rainstorm gone on longer, the flooding in the areas affected on Monday would have been considerably worse. The essential problem is that the water has to be got away to the sea, and if the drains are not big enough, it cannot get away; there is a bottleneck and the water lies around until gradually it finds its way out. This constitutes the special danger for Singapore: whilst a single storm will clear itself in a reasonable period of time, a succession of storms can lead to a very considerable accumulation of water with all the very serious danger and damage to crops, to property, to livestock and to commercial activities which are inevitably involved.

    The problem of flood control will, I am afraid, remain with Singapore for a good many years to come and will involve quite considerable cost and, consequently, quite considerable taxation before it can be fully dealt with. In the 3½ years that I have been concerned with this matter, the Government has spent, exclusive of land costs, approximately $1 million on flood control works and is committed to a further $1¼ million for completion of the Geylang Flood prevention scheme

Column: 914

and the Ulu Pandan diversion of the Queenstown flood waters. In addition, the City Council has done quite a good deal of work but I have not got precise figures for their expenditure. It is probably safe to say that the work done so far is only a small part of the work and the cost which will be necessary to give Singapore reasonable freedom from flooding in all areas.

     Hon. Members are well aware of the serious effects on Singapore of the world trade recession and they are also aware of the very considerable sums which have been found, and necessarily will have to continue to be found, to provide education for our enormously expanding school-age population and for medical and other social services. I do not want to prejudge the decisions which may be made by successive Governments after the next general elections. I cannot attempt to say what priorities may in future be attached to flood control schemes on the one hand, and to social services or to other forms of development on the other.

    There is, however, no immediate prospect of this Government undertaking any new major flood control schemes apart from the completion of the works I have referred to - at Paya Lebar, Geylang and Ulu Pan-dan. Because of this, I have reluctantly agreed to allow our Drainage Adviser to retire. In the 3½ years in which he has been working here, he has completed a massive job of making an overall survey of the causes of flooding on this island and he has worked out the schemes which will have to be carried out in order to remove the flood problem from us. He has also carried out the important scheme at Bedok and has got us well advanced with the schemes for the Geylang/Paya Lebar area and for Ulu Pandan. He has worked under great difficulties and his achievements have been limited not by his capacity but by the ability of Government to finance the necessary schemes. It is with the greatest regret that I have agreed to his retirement but he does leave behind him the general plans which can be brought into action at any time when the funds are available.
